question: The law of large numbers is fundamentally related to the meaning of probability.
If a Bayesian analysis and a frequentist analysis give the same numerical answer, you cannot say that one is better or worse than the other.
It is legitimate to model degrees of belief with probability theory.
Any model of degrees of belief that is not probability theory is wrong.
It is possible to experimentally verify that the value of a probability is correct.
Probabilities based on subjective introspection have no role in science.
Statistics education tends to emphasise classical significance testing too much.
Goodness of fit tests are important.
Laplace's principle of indifference has been unfairly maligned.
Maximum likelihood is an approximation, not a principle.
It is an experimental fact that some quantities are random and others are not.
If two people have the same information, they should have the same probabilities.
I often divide datasets into training data and validation data.
Let the data speak for themselves.
It is sometimes legitimate to say 'the probability is 50% because it either is or it isn't'.
If someone claims 70% certainty about many statements, about 70% of those statements should be true.
Symmetry is an important consideration in statistics.
It is impossible and undesirable to eradicate subjective judgement from data analysis.
